image.altText: Erin Patterson looks at the camera as she sits in the back of a prison van

props.synopsis: For 10 weeks, reporter Jarrod Whittaker witnessed the town of Morwell swell with media, money, and relentless curiosity. He also had a clear view of Erin Patterson as the jury delivered its verdict in the mushroom murder trial's final, defining moment.

title.children: Inside the courtroom covering Erin Patterson's murder trial

image.altText: A group of people pose for a photo, all are blurred except for Erin Scutter in the front row, wearing a pink top.

props.synopsis: The world has met Erin Patterson as the murderous cook behind a mushroom meal that killed three relatives. But years before her courtroom infamy, the woman from Melbourne's suburbs divided opinions.

title.children: 'She's no dope': Who is the host of Australia's most infamous lunch?

image.altText: A graphic of Erin Patterson's face against a blue watercolour background. At the edges of the image are death cap mushrooms

props.synopsis: It was an extraordinary mystery that captivated not just Australia, but the world. Here's how media across the globe has reacted to Erin Patterson's guilty verdict.

title.children: 'Bizarre, crazy, bonkers': How the world reacted to Erin Patterson's guilty verdict

image.altText: Erin Patterson passes her phone to police during a search of her home in August 2023.

props.synopsis: The jury in Erin Patterson's trial sat through weeks of evidence before convicting her of murder. Here's some of the key pieces shown to the jury during the trial.

title.children: Leftovers, a dehydrator and CCTV: The evidence that convicted Erin Patterson

image.altText: A plate with a smattering of green beans and beef Wellington, and a knife and fork.

props.synopsis: Two years ago, Erin Patterson was a mother of two from a regional town who lived a quiet life. Now, the 50-year-old has been found guilty of murdering three people with death cap mushrooms, in a trial that's made global headlines.

title.children: How a recipe of 'ultimate indulgence' became central to a murder plot

image.altText: An Indian Sikh man in cream turban, medium beard  leans against a tractor in a fruit orchid.

props.synopsis: The apple and pear industry is in a "depressing place", but new growers are still coming on board and are diversifying crops to stay afloat.

title.children: Apple and pear growers struggle, but for some it is still a dream job

image.altText: An Orange exterior shopfront wall with paint damage

props.synopsis: With a 1,000 employees and about 4,400 clients affected, aged care, disability and veterans care service provider Annecto goes into voluntary administration, leaving staff fearful for their entitlements and their clients.

title.children: Carers, clients 'devastated' as major care provider collapses

image.altText: The exterior of a restaurant with smashed glass doors and a sign that says Miznon at night time.

props.synopsis: Three people have been charged with assault, riotous behaviour and criminal damage after a group of protesters converged on an Israeli-owned restaurant in Melbourne's CBD on Friday night.

title.children: Three protesters charged over incident at Israeli restaurant in Melbourne

image.altText: Willie Rioli walks off the ground

props.synopsis: Willie Rioli speaks candidly about a tumultuous couple of months he endured this season, admitting he spoke to his manager on multiple occasions about retiring from the AFL.

title.children: Rioli considered retiring as racism and off-field drama became 'a bit too much'

image.altText: A smiling, dark-haired girl lines up a basketball to take a shot.

props.synopsis: Basketball associations say they are in desperate need of more courts, as a heavyweight of the sport voices her fear that players will be turned away if needs go unmet.

title.children: Basketball infrastructure falling behind popularity in regional areas

image.altText: Child's hand on play equipment

props.synopsis: Kids face down asleep in hoodies, electrical sockets exposed and one child locked in a shed. Documents reveal disturbing revelations from inside Australia's childcare sector in crisis.

title.children: Documents reveal shocking practices inside childcare sector in crisis

image.altText: An aerial view of wetlands.

props.synopsis: The temporary closure of Victoria's Winton Wetlands could lead to an explosion in pest numbers and undo decades of environmental programs and research, an ecologist says.

title.children: Ecologist concerned world-class wetlands could be overrun by pests

image.altText: couple looking at computer together on the couch

props.synopsis: A leading Australian fertility lawyer is urging governments to regulate the "wild west" of online semen donation, accusing them of being "asleep at the wheel".

title.children: Calls for online sperm donation to be regulated due to 'lifelong consequences'

image.altText: Stock market charts overlaid with Reserve Bank signage

props.synopsis: The RBA board holds interest rates at 3.85 per cent in a split decision, six votes to three, sending the Aussie dollar higher.

title.children: Shock RBA hold decision sends Aussie dollar higher

image.altText: benjamin netanyahu hands donald trump a note across a dining table

props.synopsis: The Israeli prime minister is expected to spend several days in Washington as Israeli and Hamas representatives take part in ceasefire negotiations in Qatar.

title.children: A Nobel Peace Prize and Gaza: What Trump and Netanyahu discussed at dinner

image.altText: An older man wearing a red tie, white shirt and a black suit jacket with a serious expression

props.synopsis: The federal government's economic think tank says Australia will likely be a winner from Donald Trump's tariffs if it does not retaliate and that we would be better off by removing more of the nation's remaining tariffs.

title.children: Trump's tariffs 'actually good' for Australia, Productivity Commission finds

image.altText: Donald Trump wearing a blue suit and white USA cap waving with his right arm raised while about to board Air Force One

props.synopsis: The US president confirmed the new levies by posting the letters sent to world leaders on social media.

title.children: Trump announces swathes of new tariffs for countries around the world

image.altText: Four people searching debris on the banks of a river. Debris is littered throughout tree branches.

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump describes the catastrophic Texas floods as a one-in-100-year event — a disaster "nobody expected". But a political debate is raging over whether cuts to the public service have played a role.

title.children: Were the Texas floods a disaster 'nobody expected' — or an avoidable catastrophe?

image.altText: Albanese g7

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese says he has not given up on convincing the Trump administration to drop its tariffs on Australia as the PM confirms he's heading to China later this week.

title.children: PM still negotiating for Trump tariff removal, confirms visit to China — as it happened

image.altText: A side-profile picture of a man in a dark suit.

props.synopsis: Former Gold Coast City councillor Ryan Bayldon-Lumsden is to stand trial in the Brisbane Supreme Court over the alleged murder in the family home in 2023.

title.children: Accused killer ex-councillor choked stepfather in kitchen, court hears

image.altText: A woman with blonde long-hair, wearing pale framed glasses, holding a white folder, leaf pattern dress standing outside

props.synopsis: In her 683-page report, Coroner Elisabeth Armitage made 32 formal recommendations for change, after an almost three-year coronial inquest into the police shooting of Kumanjayi Walker. Here are five of the key findings.

title.children: Five key takeaways from the 683-page report into Kumanjayi Walker's death

image.altText: Aboriginal man with cropped hair and goatee reading a book with the words Yes I can, other people in background.

props.synopsis: A program improving literacy rates among Indigenous adults helps more than 500 people change their lives, but advocates say much more is needed to address the problem nationally.

title.children: Adults return to the classroom to turn around literacy rates and lives

image.altText: A middle-aged man with grey-white hair wearing a grey T-shirt looks serious in front of a plain background.

props.synopsis: The US Justice Department says it has videos and pictures of Epstein and victims but will not be releasing any more files from the case as much of it is sealed by a court.

title.children: Justice Department walks back on Epstein's 'client list' claims

image.altText: A sign that reads "Bendigo Bank".

props.synopsis: The closure of 10 Bendigo Bank branches across Australia by late October will mean the end of in-person banking for residents in five regional communities.

title.children: Bendigo Bank announces closure of 10 branches in three states

image.altText: A sunset photo of a big pile of dirt and a conveyor belt in silhouette

props.synopsis: More than 2,000 labour hire workers employed by BHP in Central Queensland will be paid thousands of dollars more, in a major test of the federal government's laws requiring they be paid the same as directly employed workers.

title.children: Landmark ruling orders BHP to pay labour hire workers an average $30,000 more

image.altText: A older man in a black jacket

props.synopsis: A zookeeper who applied a makeshift tourniquet has been credited with preventing a tragedy after the attack at Darling Downs Zoo.

title.children: Zoo owner says quick thinking after lion attack saved woman's life

image.altText: Matt Cameron smiles behind the drumkit against an orange stage backrdop

props.synopsis: Pearl Jam bids farewell to their drummer Matt Cameron, who quits after 27 years with the group: "Forever our friend in art and music."

title.children: Pearl Jam drummer Matt Cameron quits band

image.altText: Workers working on digging a tunnel

props.synopsis: Work has been halted in a concrete lab at Australia's largest pumped hydro project over concerns that up to a dozen workers have been exposed to silica dust.

title.children: Concrete lab at Snowy 2.0 closes over silica exposure concerns

image.altText: Two cars driving along a highway with a road works sign nearby

props.synopsis: Pitched as a congestion buster for South West holiday traffic, the final cost of the Bussell Highway duplication in Western Australia has ballooned out by $85 million.

title.children: Cost of long-awaited South West highway duplication doubles to $170m

image.altText: a stone archway in a paddock with the bright lights of the aurora behind it

props.synopsis: On the side of Tasmania's main highway is a relic of Horton College, one of early colonial Australia's most elite schools.

title.children: This arch is a Tassie landmark, a relic of a prestigious boys' school

image.altText: Aboriginal man with grey hair.

props.synopsis: With many of Australia's Indigenous languages at risk of being lost forever, leaders from more than 30 Top End communities have come together to develop a plan to protect them.

title.children: Fears Aboriginal languages are being lost, as communities work to save them

image.altText: A farmer wearing a wide-brimmed Akubra hat looking at a golden sorghum crop.

props.synopsis: Grazier Boyd Webb is running an outback cropping experiment to get him through the next drought, growing sorghum to bury as insurance against the next big dry.

title.children: Grazier prepares for drought by growing sorghum to bury in the outback

image.altText: Crash1

props.synopsis: Australian Kaden Groves could be in line to lead Alpecin-Deceuninck after Jasper Philipsen broke his collarbone in a crash.

title.children: Groves in line to lead team after Tour stage winner breaks collarbone

image.altText: five members of Chasing Ghosts band pose against white backdrop

props.synopsis: One of the year's best, the new album from Aboriginal-led rock band Chasing Ghosts transforms tough topics into catchy, cathartic anthems.

title.children: One of 2025's best albums will make you cry, rage, reflect

image.altText: A woman of Asian appearance sits on a couch in a dressing gown, wiping her nose with a tissue while looking at her phone.

props.synopsis: If you need a medical certificate for yourself or carer's leave, what are your options if you are short on time and want to save money?

title.children: Easiest and cheapest ways to get a medical certificate for sick leave
